What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got a pretty comprehensive overview of contemporary social theory and read some very important authors (e.g. Foucault).

A good survey of the major theories and methodologies in contemporary social theory scholarship, many of which challenged my previously simplistic understanding of such concepts as religion, social construction, and economics/markets.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Interesting readings, very free flowing discussions.

Prof. Gorski was a knowledgeable professor who often asked thought-provoking questions that shaped discussions in unexpected ways. I particularly appreciated his attempts to make some of the more abstracts concepts and theories more grounded by asking questions more related to our daily experiences. Anne Marie's in-class input was was also useful for providing alternative perspectives. 

In the future, if the class size remains reasonably small, it might be good to make other students' reading responses part of the assigned readings. I find that some of our richest discussions came through such dialogue.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely - I learned a lot in this course and thoroughly enjoyed coming to class every day. Was pushed to think about conceptual frameworks differently
I would recommend this course to a student who wants to learn about social theory, even if you're not a sociology major. It's a relatively accessible course with a manageable workload.
